author: By Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
title: Welcome Back to the Champions League. Please Maintain Social Distance.
description: The plans for European soccer’s showpiece competition seem to account for every possibility. But even before the teams arrive, the coronavirus is asking hard questions.
content: Those final few minutes, just before kickoff, have been mapped out with almost military precision. At exactly 8:50 p.m. local time, a disinfected Champions League match ball will be placed on a ceremonial plinth. At 8:53 p.m., the players will leave their locker rooms. The teams will enter the field, separately, no more than two and a half minutes later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meara Sharma
title: The British Designer Paying Tribute to the Immigrant Experience
description: Transforming discarded fabrics into forward-looking men’s wear, Priya Ahluwalia draws on her family’s Nigerian and Indian roots.
content: In 1990s South London, a young Priya Ahluwalia would watch as members of her extended family got ready for garage raves, styling themselves in matching two-piece sets, dresses with chain belts and patterned silk shirts. “All the guys wore earrings,” she recalls. “I used to wish I could go party with them, too.” Perhaps her longing helped crystallize these memories, because similar pieces, such as candy-hued sweater vests, vividly patchworked hoodies and jackets made from deconstructed Levi’s, have found their way into some of the 27-year-old British men’s wear designer’s recent collections. In fact, a thread of nostalgia runs through all of Ahluwalia’s designs: In addition to drawing from the aesthetics prominent during her own childhood, she pays homage to those of other cultural epochs, as well as to her family’s Nigerian, Indian and Jamaican heritage and the broader immigrant experience in the United Kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Ambition Has Always Been ‘Ladylike’
description: Nostalgic for the sexism unleashed in response to Hillary Clinton’s 2016 run? Welcome to the prolonged Democratic veepstakes.
content: No one, it is safe to assume, told J.F.K. he was too ambitious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: When Bugs Crawl Up the Food Chain
description: We usually think of insects as meals for vertebrates such as frogs. But arthropods may turn the tables more often than you think.
content: Epomis beetle larvae look delicious to frogs. They’re snack-size, like little protein packs. If a frog is nearby, a larva will even wiggle its antennae and mandibles alluringly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Order on Coronavirus Relief Alarms Governors as Stimulus Talks Stall
description: The Trump administration is ordering schools on Native American reservations to reopen. California’s chief health officer has resigned. The pandemic has now sickened more than 20 million people, according to a Times database.
content: Governors across the United States struggled on Monday with how to make good on President Trump’s order that their economically battered states deliver billions more in unemployment benefits to jobless residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Rachlin
title: A Designer Who Got Her Discipline From Dance
description: Marina Moscone makes elegant women’s wear that privileges handcraft and meticulous attention to detail.
content: When the New York-based women’s wear designer Marina Moscone was 3, she stole her father’s burgundy leather briefcase and used it to carry around the sketches she made wherever she went. Not long after, she announced to her parents that she was becoming a fashion designer. A few years later, at age 7, she decided that she would eventually move from her native Vancouver, British Columbia, to New York to study at the Parsons School of Design. She had learned about the school while watching reruns of the Canadian TV show “Fashion File.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Gillian Friedman
title: To Withhold or Not: Trump’s Order Gives Employers a New Dilemma
description: Businesses are grappling with difficult legal and logistical questions about how to respond to the president’s payroll-tax holiday order.
content: The White House has pitched its payroll tax holiday as a boon to American workers that would fatten their paychecks and provide a jolt to the economy. But for companies large and small, the presidential intervention poses difficult legal and logistical questions that only add to the uncertainty that executives and workers are contending with during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich and Rachel Abrams
title: McDonald’s Sues Former C.E.O., Accusing Him of Lying and Fraud
description: The fast-food chain said Steve Easterbrook, who was fired last fall, concealed evidence during an investigation into his conduct.
content: Eight months had passed since McDonald’s fired its chief executive, Steve Easterbrook, for sexting with a subordinate. Mr. Easterbrook had apologized and walked away with tens of millions in compensation, and the fast-food chain had moved on under a new chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Who Opposes Defunding the N.Y.P.D.? These Black Lawmakers
description: Several Black City Council members have lashed out at progressives, comparing calls to defund the police to “colonization” and “political gentrification.”
content: With New York City on the cusp of cutting $1 billion from the Police Department, a city councilwoman, Vanessa L. Gibson, told her colleagues that enough was enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Stephen Curry Has ‘Major FOMO’ in Life Outside the N.B.A. Bubble
description: Curry led the Golden State Warriors to the N.B.A. finals for five consecutive years, but now he’s not even going to the playoffs. “You miss it badly,” he said.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: Daniela Soto-Innes Is One of the Most Exciting Chefs Working Today
description: At Cosme, Atla and now Elio, she has reimagined both Mexican cuisine and how professional kitchens are run.
content: “Can you hug?” This was one of the countless questions the chef Daniela Soto-Innes had to ask herself in May while turning Atla, her contemporary Mexican all-day cafe in New York’s NoHo neighborhood, into a takeout spot that could operate effectively while keeping its staff safe during the pandemic. She and her nine cooks were getting used to working with masks on, but were they allowed to act the way they normally did, she wondered, like some amalgamation of an athletic team and a family? And how could they translate a restaurant built to feel like a laid-back afternoon hangout into an experience people could take home in disposable containers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Multi-Light Pendants
description: Why settle for a single hanging fixture when you can have multiples? Here’s what you need to know before you buy.
content: There’s a new kind of light fixture elbowing its way into territory once dominated by the chandelier. You may have already spotted it, spreading out above dining tables and cascading down stairwells: the multi-light pendant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Stacy Cowley
title: Trump’s directives were supposed to offer relief. Most may not.
description: President Trump, in announcing his executive measures on Saturday, said he was bypassing Congress to deliver emergency pandemic aid to needy Americans. But his directives are rife with so much complexity and legal murkiness that they’re unlikely, in most cases, to bring fast relief — if any.
content: President Trump, in announcing his executive measures on Saturday, said he was bypassing Congress to deliver emergency pandemic aid to needy Americans. But his directives are rife with so much complexity and legal murkiness that they’re unlikely, in most cases, to bring fast relief — if any.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: As U.S. and Taiwan Celebrate a Bond, China Responds With Screaming Jets
description: The highest-level American visit to Taiwan in decades shows the island’s importance as ties between the United States and China deteriorate.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The United States’ top health official lauded Taiwan’s democracy and its response to the coronavirus. Taiwan’s president hailed the island’s growing economic and public health ties with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Packing 14 Up-to-the-Minute Monologues in ‘One Room’
description: A collection of short solo works from the Weston Playhouse furthers the redefinition of theater online — and of life in isolation.
content: Five months into internet exile, playgoers have a lot of questions. Two of the biggest for me are: Is what we’re seeing online really theater? And why so many monologues?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Start-Ups Braced for the Worst. The Worst Never Came.
description: The doomsday warnings about tech start-ups failing in the pandemic have not yielded the shakeout that many expected a few months ago.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Getaround, a car sharing start-up, started the year by laying off 150 employees and scaling back some operations after it spent too much on a rapid expansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Harris
title: On the Shores of Cape Cod, Where the Oyster Is Their World
description: Pollution, development and overharvesting have greatly diminished America’s natural oyster habitat. Aquaculture and adaptable farmers have changed the game.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Randy Harris shares a collection of images from the shores of Cape Cod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: A Rare Economic Bright Spot in the U.S. Health System: The Vet’s Office
description: Usually during an economic downturn, people tend to spend less on health care for pets. This time, the opposite is happening.
content: The human health care system has struggled financially through the coronavirus pandemic, losing billions from the cancellations of lucrative elective operations as patients were first told to stay away from hospitals and then were leery of setting foot in one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Nate Schweber
title: Will Cars Rule the Roads in Post-Pandemic New York?
description: Newly emboldened, many New Yorkers want to repurpose streets for walking, biking, dining and schools, even as traffic returns.
content: When New York went into lockdown five months ago to contain the virus, traffic virtually disappeared, and the mostly deserted streets suddenly became a vast trove of open space in one of the world’s most crowded cities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: August 10, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 10, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 10, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Here’s the business news to watch this week.
description: 🗣 It’s a relatively light week for earnings, with a majority of the S&P 500 having already reported their latest quarterly results. Notable releases include Simon Property Group on Monday; InterContinental Hotels and SoftBank on Tuesday; Cisco, Lyft and Tencent on Wednesday; and Applied Materials and Deutsche Telekom on Thursday.
content: 🗣 It’s a relatively light week for earnings, with a majority of the S&P 500 having already reported their latest quarterly results. Notable releases include Simon Property Group on Monday; InterContinental Hotels and SoftBank on Tuesday; Cisco, Lyft and Tencent on Wednesday; and Applied Materials and Deutsche Telekom on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daphne A. Brooks
title: 100 Years Ago, ‘Crazy Blues’ Sparked a Revolution for Black Women Fans
description: Mamie Smith’s song wasn’t just an artistic breakthrough. It proved Black women and girls bought records, paving the way for today’s fan armies.
content: “Music was my refuge.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Stanley Kubrick,’ a Brisk New Biography of a Major Talent
description: David Mikics’s entry in the Jewish Lives series captures the greatness of the director of “2001,” “The Shining” and other classics.
content: Pauline Kael was no fan of Stanley Kubrick’s movies. She deplored his “arctic spirit.” She compared “A Clockwork Orange” to the work of a Teutonic professor. In her review of “2001: A Space Odyssey,” she wrote: “It’s a bad, bad sign when a movie director begins to think of himself as a mythmaker.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why the U.S. Hasn’t Contained Covid-19
description: Readers offer their theories, including lack of funding for public health services.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Pints or Primers? U.K.’s Push to Open Schools May Force a Choice
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls it a “moral duty” to open Britain’s schools, but with cases already rising slightly, that might mean closing pubs and restaurants.
content: LONDON — Britain, having moved aggressively to reopen its economy after three months of coronavirus lockdown, now faces what some experts cast as a binary trade-off for a land that loves a good book as much as a cold pint: schools or pubs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Should a Study on Pesticides Affect Our Use of Them?
description: Recent research, which found a link between pyrethroids and deaths from heart disease, highlights the limitations of epidemiological research.
content: With summer here and more people choosing to escape their coronavirus prisons into yards, parks, woods and streets, a recent study suggests yet another potential health risk, albeit one far less concerning than the virus: exposure to pyrethroids, a major group of insecticides widely used to protect against everything from malaria parasites and West Nile virus to bed bugs and ticks, as well as a host of agricultural and garden pests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Quarantine Envy Got You Down? You’re Not Alone
description: A beach house, a suburban home, a home without children, a home filled with family: These days, everyone wants something that someone else has.
content: When the coronavirus hit France, Leila Slimani, a popular French-Moroccan novelist, and her family left Paris for their country home. Once there, Ms. Slimani began writing a quarantine diary for the newspaper Le Monde. The response, especially from people in teeny Parisian apartments, was so scathing, she apparently abandoned the series. When the billionaire David Geffen posted photos of his mega-yacht on Instagram while he quarantined in the Grenadines, the backlash led him to turn his account private.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Lebanon’s Government Resigns Amid Widespread Anger Over Blast
description: The cabinet stepped down as fury over a giant explosion last week in Beirut spurred new protests.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s cabinet resigned on Monday, opening up new political uncertainty as the country struggles with a crippling economic crisis and reels from an enormous explosion last week that ravaged swaths of the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: An Exhibition Tells the Story of a Drug War Leader, but Not All of It
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration’s exhibition on Harry J. Anslinger, a founding father of American drug policy, does not delve into criticism that he used racial slurs.
content: Harry J. Anslinger’s pioneering work as head of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics has largely been unsung, though experts see him as the founding father of America’s war on drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta Air Lines Bought an Oil Refinery. It Didn’t Go as Planned.
description: Delta’s foray into oil refining illustrates some of the reasons the business was in trouble even before the pandemic.
content: Jet fuel is known as the Steady Eddie of the refinery business, a predictable profit maker that balances the seasonal gyrations of gasoline and diesel sales. But for airlines, it is a headache — a big and unpredictable expense that confounds managers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Hockey, Rocked by Racist Acts, Embraces Black Lives Matter Campaigns
description: To a degree not seen before, players are kneeling for the United States national anthem and speaking out publicly on fighting racism, with backing from the National Hockey League.
content: Minnesota Wild forward Matt Dumba walked to center ice before an N.H.L. game this month and addressed the television audience, not about the game but the need for the sport to fight racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Roadtripping Before the D.N.C.
description: Times reporters discuss the realities of election coverage amid a pandemic.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Jennifer Medina, your host, filling in for Lisa Lerer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Sends In the Economic Quacks
description: Now he’s prescribing hydroxychloroquine to fight recession.
content: As the U.S. economy careens toward disaster, congressional talks about what to do appear to have ground to a halt. So on Saturday President Trump — speaking at one of his golf courses, of course — announced four executive measures that, he claimed, would rescue the recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘A Thousand Cuts’ Review: A Free Press Endures Lacerations
description: This documentary profiles Maria Ressa, a journalist who has fearlessly chronicled abuses in the Philippines under the Duterte government.
content: The death by a thousand cuts that gives this documentary from Ramona S. Diaz its title is the death of democracy — a slow wounding that eventually makes the democracy too weak to survive. And while that assessment, offered by the journalist Maria Ressa, refers to the Philippines under Rodrigo Duterte, the absorbing and multipronged “A Thousand Cuts” presents the country as a test lab for autocracy — and suggests that its experiments have a high potential to travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The Danish-American journalist, photographer and author Jacob RIIS (1849-1914) has been in the New York Times Crossword 180 times, most recently in Jacob Stulberg’s puzzle on Tuesday, Aug. 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York Schools Can Reopen. Will They?
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is allowing New York schools to reopen, but it's unclear what teachers and parents will do.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Murphy
title: Collin Morikawa’s Joyful Win Broke Through Golf’s Pandemic Fog
description: Morikawa, 23, delivered a dazzling final round at the P.G.A. Championship to become the long-overdue first major champion of the 2020 season.
content: As Collin Morikawa hoisted the huge Wanamaker Trophy above his head on Sunday evening, giving it a quick, jubilant shake, the lid went clattering off. Again, he was providing exactly what golf needed in a season dimmed by plague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Moss
title: The Designer Who Gives Her Pieces Minds of Their Own
description: Elizabeth Garouste’s richly layered interiors and fantastical furniture are as appealing now as they were when she first caught Paris’s attention in the ’80s.
content: As a girl, the furniture designer and artist Elizabeth Garouste had a profound fear of the furnishings and objects in her home, in Paris’s Montparnasse neighborhood. “I always thought that things around the house would furtively move themselves, that they had their own souls,” she says in her native French. Garouste was born into a Jewish family in 1946, just after World War II ended, and had a grandmother who didn’t mince words when it came to describing the recent atrocities. “I transferred a kind of terror onto everything,” Garouste reflects, “and, really, I may have decided to make furniture as a means of taming those items that I grew up with.” Her primary aim for the pieces she now creates is to endow each with a buoyant personality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasmine Wahi
title: The Artist Unraveling American History
description: Best known for her series of deconstructed flags, Sonya Clark offers poignant, clearsighted reminders of this country’s legacy of racial violence.
content: Sonya Clark’s work is unequivocally political: Her 2019 wall hanging “These days. This country. This history.” consists of the remains of an unraveled American flag onto which the unmistakable X of the Confederate battle flag, also in tatters, has been woven, the two flags hopelessly intertwined. She believes the election of Donald Trump added fuel to her fire, and indeed, these days, as we witness the continuing state-sanctioned murder of Black people, her work feels especially relevant. Yet the western Massachusetts-based Clark, 53, isn’t making work for the news cycle. While some political art can, like Trump himself, feel temporary, a product of and for its time, Clark’s goes to the root of longstanding injustices and hypocrisies woven, if not into the actual flag, then into the metaphorical fabric of American culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Michigan Democrats Hesitate on Whitmer as V.P.: ‘Selfishly, We Need Her Here’
description: She is suddenly on Joe Biden’s shortlist. Can Michigan afford to lose her?
content: WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich. — With Joseph R. Biden Jr. expected to announce his choice of running mate in the coming days, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan has suddenly joined the pack of leading contenders in the home stretch — a turn that has some Democrats in the state excited, but has left others concerned about how they, and Michigan, might fare without her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Arrests Jimmy Lai, Media Mogul, Under National Security Law
description: The pro-democracy figure is the most high-profile person detained under the sweeping legislation imposed by Beijing. “It’s hard to believe this is Hong Kong,” said a journalist.
content: HONG KONG — In a high-profile attack on free speech and dissent in Hong Kong, the police on Monday arrested Jimmy Lai, a prominent pro-democracy media tycoon, and raided the offices of his newspaper, demonstrating China’s resolve to silence the opposition and bring the city to heel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1 Finale Recap: The Defense Rests
description: On Della’s advice, Perry calls an unexpected witness to the stand. Will the gamble pay off?
content: It’s all connected. This is Perry Mason’s argument as he takes on his star witness (and a hostile one at that), Sgt. Ennis, in court. It beggars belief that an accountant like George Gannon could have executed his two accomplices (both of them professional hoods), driven across town with a bullet wound, then blown his own head off with a shotgun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: The Rising Photographer Inspired by Her Home Country
description: The Jamaica-born, London-based Amber Pinkerton makes stylish pictures that lead with her subjects’ humanity.
content: Amber Pinkerton never intended for her work to be a commentary on racism, classism or colorism, but perhaps more than any other medium, photography has an uncanny ability to reflect our reality back to us in ways both beautiful and stark. Pinkerton grew up in a creative family in what she describes as a comfortable “bubble” within uptown Kingston, Jamaica. As a child, she would watch her mother making mosaics in the courtyard of their home, her aunts sewing clothes and her older brother sketching anime characters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Taking Protest to the Streets, and the Mayor’s Front Door
description: City leaders and public health officials are now seeing protests outside their own homes, with some protesters wielding bullhorns, spray paint, and even eggs and paintballs.
content: SEATTLE — The city was exploring a proposal to cut 50 percent of the police department’s budget to promote racial justice and alternatives to policing last month, but Debora Juarez, the first enrolled Native American on the Seattle City Council, was not yet willing to throw her support behind such a steep cut without a plan for how to carry it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Merrell Hambleton
title: The Artist Making Bulbous, Colorful Sculptures Out of Thrifted Clothes
description: Each of Aiko Hachisuka’s intricate, hand-stitched pieces is a meditation on memory, materiality and domestic labor.
content: When, as a young girl in Nagoya, Japan, Aiko Hachisuka observed her mother and grandmother sewing, she didn’t quite know what they were doing — maybe mending a sock or attaching buttons, she thinks now — but she was keenly aware that they were not to be disturbed. “I was very attracted to that focus, and the creative headspace that they were in,” she says. It was the closest thing to a studio practice that she had been exposed to. “I knew I needed to have work myself,” she says. “My first attempt at that was to go and buy a sketchbook.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift, No. 1 Again, Is Last to Benefit From an Obscure Chart Rule
description: When a physical album is sold, it often comes with a digital copy. Which one counts in Billboard’s totals is changing.
content: Taylor Swift, who holds the No. 1 album for a second time with “Folklore,” may be one of the last stars to benefit from Billboard’s so-called bundling rule, which lets artists sell albums with merchandise or concert tickets. Long criticized for distorting the charts, that guideline is set to be curtailed in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Purnick
title: What Your Recipe Box Says About You
description: Quarantine has given a former New York Times columnist the time to come to grips with a lifetime’s worth of clipped and faded recipes.
content: This is it. The perfect time. What better distraction as I continue to dodge a deadly virus, mourn those who could not, worry about my country’s soul and find comic relief in links that I obsessively impose on friends and family?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Catholic Churches Drop Hymns After Accusations Against Composer
description: David Haas, a composer known for “Blest Are They,” “We Are Called,” “You Are Mine” and other favorites, has been accused of sexual abuse and harassment by multiple women, an advocacy group says.
content: Several Roman Catholic archdioceses have banned a well-known liturgical composer from performing in their churches and many others have stopped playing his music after dozens of women accused him of sexual misconduct and harassment over more than 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Annie Karni
title: Trump Teases a Gettysburg Convention Speech. Experts Say It’s an Ethics Breach.
description: If he accepts his nomination at the Civil War battlefield, the president will be conducting partisan business on federal property.
content: After repeatedly throwing a wrench into plans for the Republican National Convention this summer, President Trump on Monday tried to offer something tantalizing about the upcoming gathering, saying that his renomination speech would take place either at the White House or the Civil War battlefield in Gettysburg, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Schroeder
title: What if Some Kids Are Better Off at Home?
description: For parents like me, the pandemic has come with a revelation: For our children, school was torture.
content: In the early morning hours of Monday, March 9, I was locked in battle with my oldest son, Izac, then a freshman in high school, over what felt like his one-billionth request to skip his 7 a.m. physical education class. He said he was tired and anxious and begged for a break. I told him that when you commit to something, you show up. End of story. And so off he went to school, bleary-eyed and resentful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Led From Briefing Room After a Shooting Outside the White House
description: The Secret Service stopped President Trump in the middle of a coronavirus briefing and escorted him to the Oval Office. He returned several minutes later, and said there had been a shooting nearby.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump was abruptly pulled out of the White House Briefing Room in midsentence during a televised news conference on Monday after a shooting near the Executive Mansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Fay Chew Matsuda, Steward of Chinese Immigrant Legacy, Dies at 71
description: A social worker turned preservationist, she directed the Museum of Chinese in America. “Sometimes it was literally dumpster-diving,” she said of rescuing artifacts.
content: Fay Chew Matsuda, a first-generation Chinese-American who devoted her career as an amateur museum curator to preserving the heritage of overlooked generations of immigrants from China, died on July 24 at her home in Sound Beach, N.Y., on Long Island’s North Shore. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Christine Hauser and Johnny Diaz
title: Chicago Police Arrest More Than 100 People After Looting Batters Downtown
description: The city briefly raised most of the bridges to the main shopping and business district. Mayor Lori Lightfoot condemned the crowd’s actions as “abject criminal behavior.”
content: CHICAGO — All summer, demonstrators have marched through Chicago to protest police misconduct. In many neighborhoods, gun violence has been unrelenting, soaring to levels not seen in decades. The coronavirus pandemic is resurging, now sickening hundreds of people each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Aramco’s profit fell 73 percent as demand for oil shrank.
description: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Sunday that its quarterly earnings plunged more than 73 percent compared to a year ago, as lockdowns imposed to curb the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut the demand for oil and slammed prices.
content: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Sunday that its quarterly earnings plunged more than 73 percent compared to a year ago, as lockdowns imposed to curb the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut the demand for oil and slammed prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Algerian Journalist Sentenced to 3 Years for Reporting on Protests
description: The journalist Khaled Drareni was convicted after reporting on the Hirak protest movement, which forced the removal of the country’s longtime ruler, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, last year.
content: A prominent Algerian journalist was sentenced to three years in prison Monday for reporting on anti-government demonstrations, a lawyer and a human rights official said. It’s the latest sign of a hardening crackdown on the press in Algeria, one that has drawn condemnation from international observers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How Pro-Trump Forces Work the Refs in Silicon Valley
description: The new referees in American politics are Facebook, Google and Twitter, and they would be wise to pay attention to lessons the old media tried to learn.
content: One of the oddest moments during last month’s tech hearings on Capitol Hill came when a Florida congressman darkly hinted that Google was making it difficult for him to find a website he was looking for, The Gateway Pundit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: How Are You Doing?
description: Sometimes it feels like the only pleasure available in the day is cooking.
content: Good morning. How are you doing? It’s been five months now, for some of us, living and working at home, or living at home and doing essential work out in the world, or living at home and not working anywhere. We’re stuck with the kids, the parents, the pod or ourselves alone, together apart, apart together. Grocery runs, a wait at the post office, protests, gas for the truck. Sometimes it feels as if the only pleasure available in the day comes when we can step away, finally, to cook, to make something delicious, something to take our minds off the state of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: A Push to Return U.K.’s ‘Motor City’ to Its Cycling Roots
description: Coventry can be forbidding for cyclists. But before it became Britain’s Detroit, the city was famed for making bicycles.
content: COVENTRY, England — Through leafy suburban streets, then up and over a narrow bridge, the path for cyclists heading north into Coventry seems smooth and easy until it ends abruptly — at a busy four-lane “ring road” with no on ramp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: The First Round of the N.H.L. Playoffs Is Set. There Have Already Been Upsets.
description: The top seeds in the Western and Eastern play-in tournaments were eliminated, and the No. 1 teams in the round robin slid to fourth as the first round is set to begin Tuesday.
content: The Stanley Cup playoffs began as an experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sahan Hapangama, Louis Gelabert and Sarah Norris
title: ‘The Wounds Are Still Fresh’
description: These front-line medical workers are struggling with what comes next.
content: Once a global epicenter of the pandemic, New York City has — for now — brought things under control. But where does this reprieve leave front-line medical workers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Never a Dull Moment in Trump World
description: ‘One thing I have to give Trump credit for is a general lowering of expectations.’
content: Gail Collins: Bret, did you listen to the president’s weekend address? The one he gave to an audience composed of members at his private golf club? The part where he said Democrats don’t love the country?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: Marcus Stroman Becomes Second Mets Player to Opt Out
description: Stroman’s departure is another blow to the team’s pitching staff, which was already without the injured Noah Syndergaard.
content: A day after finally providing some run support for their ace, Jacob deGrom, and winning a weekend series against the Miami Marlins, the Mets appeared to be enjoying an upswing after an underwhelming start to their season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Should Montreal Subway Honor Polarizing Priest or Jazz Genius?
description: A fight to rename a metro stop pits those who want to celebrate a revered Black musician against those who want to retain the name of a priest who espoused equal rights for Francophone Quebecers — and also anti-Semitism.
content: MONTREAL — Steps away from Montreal’s historically Black neighborhood of Little Burgundy, the handsome gray-stone house where the Canadian jazz virtuoso Oscar Peterson grew up sits conspicuously empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Salmonella Cases Linked to Onions Increase to Nearly 900
description: Grocery chains, including Publix and Giant Eagle, have recalled onions supplied by Thomson International and products that may contain the onions.
content: A salmonella outbreak linked to onions has expanded to 43 states and Canada, prompting a recall from a producer in California and various grocery chains, health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: When Things Aren’t OK With a Child’s Mental Health
description: Everyone is stressed and anxious now. We have to find and help the children who are hurting most.
content: Last week, to write about the risks of summer — the recurring safety issues of children being out in the sun, or near the water, I talked to safety-minded pediatric emergency room doctors about what was worrying them, as they thought about the children they might be seeing during their shifts over the coming weeks, and I specified that I wasn’t asking about Covid-19 infection — I was asking about other dangers to children, in this summer shadowed by that virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Niven Patel, a Miami Chef, Is Not Giving Up on 2020
description: A return to indoor dining may be far off, but he just opened a new, Caribbean-inspired restaurant and is moving ahead with plans for others.
content: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — The last week in July was an especially stressful one for Niven Patel, and for Floridians in general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Stimulus, Border Rule, Conventions: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed’s Main Street program funneled its first loans to casinos, roofers and dentists.
description: The Federal Reserve released detailed data on Monday on its first-ever attempt to get loans to midsize businesses, and the figures show that the program is reaching a diverse — if tiny — set of borrowers.
content: The Federal Reserve released detailed data on Monday on its first-ever attempt to get loans to midsize businesses, and the figures show that the program is reaching a diverse — if tiny — set of borrowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Chu
title: Why Is China Coming After Americans Like Me in the U.S.?
description: China wants to swallow up Hong Kong’s remaining freedoms. But it can’t be allowed to arrest, on American soil, a U.S. citizen.
content: WASHINGTON —  On Thursday, July 30, I fell asleep watching reruns of “Law and Order.” The next morning, I woke up a fugitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: Porsha in Protest
description: On “The Real Housewives of Atlanta,” Porsha Williams is a glamorous goofball. In real life, she’s become a crusader against police violence.
content: “Everybody should enjoy ‘The Real Housewives of Atlanta,’” said Porsha Williams, the doe-eyed star of same, whose comedic verve and penchant for interpersonal chaos have made her one of the most popular cast members on one of the most popular shows on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Global Internet Is a Mirage
description: The TikTok deal risks fracturing the internet. But let’s be honest, it’s always been fractured.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cancel Culture, Part 1: Where It Came From
description: Many people claim to have been “canceled.” What does that mean? And how did it start?
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Gillian Friedman
title: Without a $600 weekly benefit, jobless Americans face bleak choices.
description: Until a few days ago, most analysts expected Congress to agree on a new emergency spending bill that would include at least a partial extension of the extra unemployment benefits, perhaps including retroactive payments for the period when the program lapsed.
content: Until a few days ago, most analysts expected Congress to agree on a new emergency spending bill that would include at least a partial extension of the extra unemployment benefits, perhaps including retroactive payments for the period when the program lapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coco Romack
title: A Designer Making Clothes for Black Femmes — and for Everyone Else, Too
description: With help from those in her creative community, Pierre Davis has created a truly inclusive brand in No Sesso.
content: One February during New York Fashion Week, rays of sunlight poured through the windows of Chelsea’s Pier 59 Studios, setting off a glimmer of rhinestones across the butt of a belly-bearing gray velour tracksuit. As the model Maya Monés, her ’60s-inspired shoulder-length wig flipped upward at the ends, made the customary spin at the edge of the catwalk, she brushed her palms across two short words spelled out by the gems, the declaration of a singular presence: “No Sesso.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The road to reopening schools in the U.S. keeps getting rockier.
content: The road to reopening for U.S. schools keeps getting rockier, with new research reflecting just how vulnerable children can be to the coronavirus. At the same time, some American parents, fearful of the potential consequences of remote learning, have filed lawsuits to demand in-person classes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Have a Cure for the Dog Days of Summer
description: It’s hot, Donald Trump is still president, the pandemic is still raging, and did I mention that it’s hot?
content: NASHVILLE — August and February are the two months I like least. August because it’s hot and dry and the wildflowers are mostly spent. February because it’s cold and gray and by February I have lived too long without wildflowers. Thanks to climate change, February doesn’t get all that cold anymore, though it’s still gray. February will always be gray in Middle Tennessee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: Washington N.F.L. Team Owner Files Claims Hinting at a Conspiracy
description: Daniel Snyder is seeking documents from a former employee to bolster his case asserting a campaign to damage him is being waged as shareholders seek to sell their stake in the team.
content: Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Football Team, has accused a disgruntled former team employee of taking money and assisting in a campaign to spread damaging information against him, his latest effort to fight back attacks on his ownership of the N.F.L. club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Made in Italy’ Review: Father and Son Reunion
description: The sale of a Tuscan villa forces a grieving widower and his troubled son to reconnect in this trite comic drama.
content: The title promises “Made in Italy,” but I wouldn’t get too excited. Oh, there’s pretty scenery (including the requisite cypress trees), and a villa to yearn for, even in its dusty, dilapidated state. But for a movie that’s supposedly meant to lift us off our couches and set us down in a verdant dreamscape, this limp foreign-soil fantasy from James D’Arcy doesn’t come close to getting the job done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: After a Flop, Amazon Makes Another Foray Into Video Games
description: Amazon said it was rebranding Twitch Prime, in another attempt to crack the video game market after a big-budget game effort failed.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — Amazon stumbled as it worked to break into the lucrative video game industry. Now it’s trying again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Billy Witz
title: In Push to Play, College Football Stars Show Sudden Unity
description: The blending of athletes’ #WeAreUnited and #WeWantToPlay campaigns showed students asserting themselves in ways that have been uncommon (and often stifled) in college sports.
content: Five years ago this month, a push to unionize college football players ended in defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: 1 Dies and at Least 7 Are Injured in Baltimore Gas Explosion
description: Three brick rowhouses were destroyed in the blast, and firefighters searched by hand for more people who might be trapped in the pile of wreckage.
content: A gas explosion leveled three rowhouses in a northwest Baltimore neighborhood on Monday morning, leaving a woman dead and at least seven other people injured, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: The Artist and Filmmaker Envisioning a Safer World for Black Women
description: Interspersing found footage with original interviews, Ja’Tovia Gary makes poetic video works that elucidate the realities of racial injustice — and how the country might change.
content: Ti’jhae Beecher is 7 years old when she happens upon the artist and filmmaker Ja’Tovia Gary on the corner of West 116th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem in 2019. Gary, flanked by a camera crew and with a microphone in hand, had stopped her to ask a simple question: “Do you feel safe?” Beecher, who is standing with her grandfather, answers yes and proceeds to tell Gary about how she feels prepared to leave the house every day, but that there are times when she is upset about having to wake up early for school. Gary agrees that waking up early is, in fact, the worst, and then asks Beecher if, for the most part, she feels good. Beecher replies plainly: “I don’t feel like I’m in danger.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Capone’ and ‘The Titan Games’
description: A biopic about the aging crime boss starring Tom Hardy arrives on Amazon. And an athletic competition show on NBC closes out its second season.
content: CAPONE (2020) Stream on Amazon and Kanopy; rent on Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. The Al Capone of this film is not the iconic bootlegger and crime boss that audiences are likely familiar with. He’s just spent 11 years in federal prison for tax evasion, and neurosyphilis is claiming his mind. As portrayed by Tom Hardy, Capone is “a boogeyman bloated with body fluids,” according to Ben Kenigsberg’s review for The Times. During this twilight period, the retired gangster lives in Palm Island, Fla., in the care of his wife, Mae (Linda Cardellini), and a doctor played by Kyle MacLachlan. Still under surveillance by law enforcement and haunted by the crimes he committed as a younger man, Capone struggles to recall where he hid millions of dollars before he was imprisoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Lebanon’s government, Jimmy Lai, Causeway Bay Books: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Prime Minister Hassan Diab and his cabinet resigned on Monday, opening up a political void as the country reels from an enormous explosion last week in Beirut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Citrus Flavoring Is Weaponized Against Insect-Borne Diseases
description: The E.P.A. has approved nootkatone, which is found in cedars and grapefruit. It repels ticks, mosquitoes and other dangerous bugs for hours, but is safe enough to eat.
content: Adding a new weapon to the fight against insect-borne illnesses like Lyme disease and malaria, the Environmental Protection Agency on Monday approved a new chemical that both repels and kills ticks and mosquitoes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Big Finance, Big Tech and Joe Biden
description: Although they haven’t necessarily fallen in love with the Democratic presidential candidate, many on Wall Street and in Silicon Valley are falling in line.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Biden’s V.P. Pick Is Said to Be Imminent
description: Joe Biden’s advisers are planning an announcement for the middle of the week as his search concludes, people briefed on the selection process said.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has told allies that he has interviewed every finalist in his vice-presidential search, and his advisers are planning an announcement for the middle of the week, people briefed on the selection process said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Floats Gettysburg as Site for Nomination Speech
description: President Trump was momentarily evacuated from the White House briefing room during a news conference. The Obamas, the Clintons, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and a former Republican governor will speak during the Democratic convention.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder
title: In Niger, an Architect Looking to the Country’s Design Traditions
description: Eschewing a Western definition of modernity, Mariam Kamara instead conceives of buildings and spaces that account for how people really live.
content: At age 6, the architect Mariam Kamara moved with her family from Niamey, the capital of Niger, deep into the country’s vast Saharan interior, not far from the 15th-century city of Agadez, where the narrow streets of the historic center are lined with centuries-old houses built from rust-red adobe. During their five years in the desert, Kamara and her father, a mining engineer, traveled frequently into the nearby mountains, where they visited caves rich with neolithic paintings and polished stone, remnants of a time when the area was green and populated by nomads. “This open archaeological site really gave me a sense of what my region is about,” says Kamara, 41, who splits her time between Providence, R.I., where her husband is a professor of computer science at Brown University, and Niamey, where her firm, Atelier Masomi, has operated since 2014. “It’s not the story we’re fed about Africa being this place with no history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Murphy
title: Collin Morikawa Delivers Magic at the P.G.A. Championship
description: In the first major tournament since the pandemic stalled the sports world, the title went to a magnetic 23-year-old who turned pro just last year.
content: In a sports year upended by the coronavirus pandemic, championship moments have been long awaited, and Collin Morikawa created an extraordinary one on Sunday at the 102nd P.G.A. Championship at T.P.C. Harding Park in San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Osman Ahmed
title: The Designer Bringing Traditional Persian Fabrics to British Men’s Wear
description: With her paisley prints and contemporary silhouettes, Paria Farzaneh shares her singular perspective with an ever-widening audience.
content: This past January, during men’s fashion week in London, the designer Paria Farzaneh invited guests to an East London boys’ school for an Iranian wedding. A bride sat onstage in a traditional white lace gown before a banquet of Persian pastries and urns overflowing with pastel-colored roses and baby’s breath. The groom, seated next to her, wore a paisley-printed ski jacket, its high, mouth-covering neck pre-empting the protective masks of the pandemic. An older community leader in a black suit presided over the faux ceremony in Farsi, as the viewers sat divided by gender — men on one side of the aisle, women on the other, though the men outnumbered the women and ended up infringing on their section. This was a deliberate move on Farzaneh’s part intended to highlight the power imbalance she feels in her industry — where a woman truly at the helm of her own brand is still something of a rarity — and was typical of the subtle gestures toward the tensions of our present moment that are embedded in her line. At the end of the ceremony, the groom rose and strode down the aisle, followed by a procession of young men dressed in looks from the fall 2020 collection of Farzaneh’s namesake line, which combined the swagger and oversize silhouettes of streetwear with the understated, earthy palette of hand-printed Iranian textiles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Welcome Return of the Chicks
description: How would Nashville be different if it hadn’t pushed the trio away? A conversation about “Gaslighter” and beyond.
content: After the killing of George Floyd and the protests for racial justice that followed, the Dixie Chicks finally unloaded their old name because of its unwelcome associations with the Old South. After rebranding as the Chicks, the group released “Gaslighter,” its first new album in 14 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Sure? No. But Rob Manfred Is Still Optimistic About This Season.
description: “We can continue to do this in a way that’s safe,” M.L.B.’s commissioner said of completing the campaign, despite two outbreaks so far.
content: In ordinary times, a baseball fan might wake up in the wee hours of the morning and check the late-night scores. In the throes of a pandemic, the sport’s commissioner wakes up around the same time and checks the overnight coronavirus test results for the 30 major league teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Wayne Fontana, Hitmaker With ‘The Game of Love,’ Dies at 74
description: The song brought him and his British invasion band, The Mindbenders, a bit of success in the mid-1960s. Then he went solo, and the hits did not keep coming.
content: Wayne Fontana, a British Invasion-era singer best known for his 1965 hit song “Game of Love,” died on Thursday at a hospital in Stockport, England. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Start-ups braced for the worst, but the worst never came.
description: When the coronavirus pandemic first hit in March, many technology start-ups braced themselves for The End, as business dried up, venture capitalists warned of dark times ahead and restructuring experts predicted the beginning of a “great unwinding” after a decade-long boom.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic first hit in March, many technology start-ups braced themselves for The End, as business dried up, venture capitalists warned of dark times ahead and restructuring experts predicted the beginning of a “great unwinding” after a decade-long boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Botched Primary Election Creates New Crisis in Puerto Rico: ‘This Is a Travesty’
description: Puerto Ricans lost confidence in their electoral system after ballots failed to reach polling places, forcing officials to partially suspend a primary.
content: Puerto Rican politics became engulfed on Monday in the confusing aftermath of a chaotic primary election that was partially suspended over the weekend when paper ballots failed to reach voting precincts, making it impossible for many people to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Estrin
title: An Interview With the Health Officer for Santa Cruz
description: Dr. Gail Newel has taken the heat as Santa Cruz went from being one of the safest coastal counties in the state to the site of a recent surge.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aisha Harris
title: Juliana Huxtable’s Next Chapter
description: The artistic polymath has pushed the limits of genre, exploring ideas about gender and politics in nearly every form imaginable.
content: Juliana Huxtable is not one to sit idle. Since graduating from Bard College in 2010, she has leapt between various corners of the New York arts scene: as the host of Shock Value, a semiregular transgender-inclusive party; as a model; as a member of the arts collective House of Ladosha; and as a creator and performer who has both D.J.ed and shown work at major museums. Coming off her last art show — an array of off-kilter multimedia work titled “Interfertility Industrial Complex: Snatch the Calf Back” that opened at Reena Spaulings Fine Art in New York this past fall — her plan was to focus for a bit on her music, traveling the world for D.J. and music gigs she’d lined up in cities ranging from Amsterdam to Novi Sad, Serbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $630,000 Homes in California
description: A two-bedroom cottage in Oakland, a 1940 house in Sacramento and a two-bedroom condominium in Culver City.
content: This house, at the end of a quiet cul-de-sac in the Fruitvale neighborhood, is within walking distance of a pocket park and an athletic field, as well as a public elementary school. Less than a mile away is Peralta Hacienda Historical Park, a complex that includes the footprints of two adobe homes built in the early 19th century and an 1870 farmhouse where there are exhibits on local history and culture. The nearest BART station is about a 10-minute drive, and downtown Oakland is about 15 minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Trump Goes Around Congress to Provide Pandemic Relief
description: It’s unclear whether the measures he signed will have any immediate effect, but the president pressed ahead anyway: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: President Trump, a self-proclaimed master at making deals, again opted for executive action over negotiation with Congress. And, yes, we’re still waiting for Joe Biden to pick a running mate. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Vu
title: The Acclaimed Soba Maker Who Champions Home Cooking
description: Working out of her California kitchen, Sonoko Sakai pays homage to Japanese culinary traditions through recipes, food activism and intimate classes.
content: Wandering among the artisanal shops of Kamakura, Japan, with her grandmother, a young Sonoko Sakai used to watch with fascination as tofu makers, tea roasters and rice millers crafted their products by hand. There was a fishmonger who delicately sliced and dried his fish on wire mesh screens, and a senbei (rice cracker) maker who sat on a tatami mat turning over each crisp, aromatic disc with chopsticks above a charcoal grill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amit Majmudar
title: Identical Twins With Two Very Different Destinies
description: A father looks to science and faith to understand his son's congenital heart defect.
content: After we had our twin sons, we took pictures of them together and separately. The pictures taken separately always kept up a certain symmetry: If we snapped one twin propped on a couch, or in the bouncer, or resting his chin on his grandmother’s shoulder, we made sure to get the other twin in the same pose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Paulina Villegas
title: ‘I’d Rather Stay Home and Die’
description: A fear of hospitals is leading many Mexicans to delay treatment for coronavirus until it is too late for doctors to help them.
content: MEXICO CITY — A gray Suzuki stopped outside the General Hospital of Mexico and deposited a heaving Victor Bailón at the entrance. He had refused to come to the hospital for days, convinced that doctors were killing coronavirus patients. By the time he hobbled into the triage area and collapsed on the floor, it was too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Jonathan Majors on ‘Lovecraft Country’: Horror as a Full Body Scream
description: The actor talked about starring in the new HBO series, which blends the supernatural with a critique of American racial injustice, and about how acting saved his future.
content: Jonathan Majors knows what makes him an exceptional actor. “I’m willing to hurt more,” he said. “I’m just willing to hurt. It doesn’t bother me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Emily Cochrane, Sarah Mervosh and Alan Rappeport
title: Governors Say Trump’s Order on Pandemic Relief Could Wreck State Budgets
description: With Congress at an impasse on stimulus talks, disarray over resuming negotiations bodes poorly for reaching a deal this week.
content: WASHINGTON — Governors across the United States struggled on Monday with how to make good on President Trump’s order that their economically battered states deliver billions more in unemployment benefits to jobless residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Nate Schweber
title: With No Power, 90,000 Struggle in a ‘Nightmare’ a Week After Storm
description: For residents of Connecticut and New York who are still without power, frustration with utility companies grew as temperatures rose.
content: After Darren Demeterio was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer last year, a scan in June detected a new cancerous spot on his liver. His doctor told him to to eat healthily and stay positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: E.P.A. to Lift Obama-Era Controls on Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
description: The reversal is the latest move in the Trump administration’s ongoing effort to weaken environmental rules, but it could be quickly undone after the November election.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is expected in the coming days to lift Obama-era controls on the release of methane, a powerful climate-warming gas that is emitted from leaks and flares in oil and gas wells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Beirut, Hong Kong, Belarus Elections: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Boucher
title: AIDS Quilts for an Artist and His Partner, Sewn During a New Pandemic
description: Tom Rauffenbart had resolved to create a tribute to his partner, the artist David Wojnarowicz. A sewing circle of women took up the cause for both men, stitching through lockdown.
content: Since the fall of 2019, six women, some from the art world, others retired social workers, had labored on two AIDS quilts devoted to the memories of the artist David Wojnarowicz and his partner, Tom Rauffenbart. The women converged from all over New York City on the neighborhood of Washington Heights, at the home of Anita Vitale, who had met Mr. Rauffenbart, a fellow social worker, in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Holly Humberstone Wants Her Songs to Last a Lifetime
description: The young British singer, who writes conversationally intimate pop music, is about to release her debut EP.
content: When the singer and songwriter Holly Humberstone began working with the writer and producer Rob Milton on her debut EP, they quickly arrived at a shorthand for the kinds of lyrics they were aiming for.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Yorkers Step Up to Preserve Composting
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 10, 2020.
content: “It’s not free. It doesn’t mean it’s not the right thing to do, but it’s not free.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Big Tech Makes Inroads With the Biden Campaign
description: While Joe Biden has criticized the largest tech companies, his campaign and transition teams have welcomed allies of Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple onto its staff and policy groups.
content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been critical of Big Tech, admonishing Facebook for mishandling misinformation and saying internet companies should lose a central legal protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: The Jewelry Designer Inspired by Ancient Rituals and Artifacts
description: Drawing on years of research and working with one of Jaipur’s premier enamel artisans, Alice Cicolini makes pieces destined to become talismans.
content: It’s telling that it was an artifact, not a stone or a vintage bauble, that set the London-based designer Alice Cicolini on her path to making jewelry. Thirteen years ago, while working as the director of arts and culture at the British Council in India, Cicolini traveled to Mehrangarh, a resplendent 15th-century fort and series of palaces with an accompanying museum in Jodhpur. Among the collection of courtly textiles, armory and miniature paintings, a maharani jewelry box caught her eye. “It would have housed many of the things you need to perform solah shringar,” she explains, referring to the ancient Hindu practice of a bride on her wedding day wearing 16 traditional adornments, from bell-embellished anklets to glass and gold bangles. “The box itself was fairly ordinary looking, but the idea of what its contents constituted was magic to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
title: Biden’s Choice
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Joe Biden is likely to reveal his pick for vice president shortly. Aides say they expect a public announcement before next week’s Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Amazon Satellites Add to Astronomers’ Worries About the Night Sky
description: The F.C.C. approved the company’s 3,236-satellite constellation, which aims to provide high-speed internet service around the world.
content: Welcome to the age of the satellite megaconstellation. Within the next few years, vast networks, containing hundreds or even thousands of spacecraft, could reshape the future of Earth’s orbital environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Creeden
title: A Floral Designer Who Forages in the Hills of Malibu
description: Using unexpected materials to create lush arrangements, Sophia Moreno-Bunge brings the Californian wilderness indoors.
content: Sophia Moreno-Bunge sees possibilities for floral design everywhere: in mushrooms, seaweed, driftwood, bread, tomatoes on the vine. “It’s the weird, overlooked, maybe forgotten things,” she says of the materials that capture her imagination and coalesce in unexpected arrangements that might combine plumes of papyrus, say, with waxy chartreuse anthuriums and a branch of ripening green lemons. Indeed, Moreno-Bunge is part of a new wave of designers — among them the Berlin-based studio Mary Lennox and the New York-based Joshua Werber — for whom the term florist seems too narrow a definition; they’re artists who not only confirm the obvious appeal of blooms but also reveal the magnificence of their landscapes’ less flamboyant elements: leaves, vegetables, seedpods, weeds and humble grasses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Don’t Credit the G.O.P. on Climate Change Just Yet
description: The Sierra Club says the party’s embrace of carbon capture isn’t enough.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Khosrowshahi
title: I Am the C.E.O. of Uber. Gig Workers Deserve Better.
description: Gig workers want both flexibility and benefits — we support laws that could make that possible.
content: Since the first Uber trip 10 years ago, one existential question has shadowed us: Do we treat drivers well?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: England’s Flawed Virus Contact Tracing Will Be Revamped
description: After months of complaints about its centralized, privatized system, Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government says resources will be diverted to local public health authorities.
content: England will overhaul its faltering coronavirus contact-tracing system, the government said on Monday, shifting some control from private contractors to local public health teams and cutting the jobs of thousands of call center workers who had complained of having no one to call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Caitlin Dickerson
title: Trump Considers Banning Re-entry by Citizens Who May Have Coronavirus
description: Under the proposal, the government could block a citizen or legal resident’s entry if an official “reasonably believes” the person had been exposed to or was infected with the communicable disease.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump is considering new immigration rules that would allow border officials to temporarily block an American citizen or legal permanent resident from returning to the United States from abroad if the authorities have reason to believe the person may be infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump Moves to Force Manhattan D.A. to Reveal Details of Inquiry
description: Lawyers for the president said a subpoena seeking eight years of tax returns amounted to illegal “harassment.”
content: President Trump, seeking to block a subpoena for his tax returns, plans to ask a federal judge to order the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to disclose details about his investigation into the president’s business practices, according to a letter filed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: She Explains ‘Mansplaining’ With Help From 17th-Century Art
description: In her new book “Men to Avoid in Art and Life,” Nicole Tersigni harnesses her skill with a Twitter meme to illuminate the experience of women harassed by concern trolls, “sexperts” and more.
content: This story begins, as so many do these days, on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Rangers Score First Pick in the N.H.L. Draft
description: After getting swept out of the postseason qualifying tournament, the Rangers won the No. 1 overall pick in the 2020 draft. The team has had six first-round picks in the past three years.
content: A month and a half after the initial phase of the N.H.L. draft lottery was held, the Rangers won No. 1 selection and the opportunity to select the consensus top prospect Alexis Lafreniere, a dazzling 18-year-old wing from Quebec.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: Belarus’s Leader Vows to Crush Protests After Claiming Landslide Election Win
description: Violent clashes between the police and protesters erupted across Belarus on Monday after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko declared victory in a vote widely dismissed as fraudulent.
content: MINSK — A day after the leader of Belarus, often called “Europe’s last dictator,” claimed a landslide re-election victory, his capital slipped into mayhem late on Monday as protesters barricaded streets and riot police officers beat back crowds of demonstrators with violent baton charges, stun grenades, tear gas and rubber bullets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Stephen Hahn, F.D.A. Chief, Is Caught Between Scientists and the President
description: Many medical experts — including members of his own staff — worry about whether Dr. Hahn has the fortitude and political savvy to protect the scientific integrity of the F.D.A. from Mr. Trump.
content: As the coronavirus surged across the Sunbelt, President Trump told a crowd gathered at the White House on July 4 that 99 percent of virus cases are “totally harmless.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mark Cuban Wants to Fix Health Care, the N.B.A. and Maybe Everything Else
description: "I’m just looking to say — and this may be arrogant — how can I solve this problem?"
content: "I’m just looking to say — and this may be arrogant — how can I solve this problem?"

title: What Happens to Viral Particles on the Subway
description: Many New Yorkers are avoiding the subway, fearful of jostling with strangers in crowded cars. Masks and social distancing are essential, but good air flow is also key to reducing the risk of exposure to the coronavirus.
